# Diagrams

## About

This page documents some tips for making diagrams in Quarto.

## Mermaid

<http://mermaid.js.org>

### Stock example

From <https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/diagrams.html>

```{mermaid}
%%| label: fig-quarto-mermaid-default
flowchart LR
  A[Hard edge] --> B(Round edge)
  B --> C{Decision}
  C --> D[Result one]
  C --> E[Result two]
```

I don't like that the text overflows the shapes.

### [Mermaid.live](https://mermaid.live) example

```{mermaid}
flowchart TD
    A[Christmas] -->|Get money| B(Go shopping)
    B --> C{Let me think}
    C -->|One| D[Laptop]
    C -->|Two| E[iPhone]
    C -->|Three| F[fa:fa-car Car]
```

## Graphviz

<https://graphviz.org>

### Stock example

From <https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/diagrams.html#graphviz>

```{dot}
//| label: fig-quarto-graphviz-default
graph G {
  layout=neato
  run -- intr;
  intr -- runbl;
  runbl -- run;
  run -- kernel;
  kernel -- zombie;
  kernel -- sleep;
  kernel -- runmem;
  sleep -- swap;
  swap -- runswap;
  runswap -- new;
  runswap -- runmem;
  new -- runmem;
  sleep -- runmem;
}
```


## DiagrammeR package

<https://rich-iannone.github.io/DiagrammeR/index.html>

### Stock example

```{r}
DiagrammeR::grViz("
digraph boxes_and_circles {

  # a 'graph' statement
  graph [overlap = true, fontsize = 10]

  # several 'node' statements
  node [shape = box,
        fontname = Helvetica]
  A; B; C; D; E; F

  node [shape = circle,
        fixedsize = true,
        width = 0.9] // sets as circles
  1; 2; 3; 4; 5; 6; 7; 8

  # several 'edge' statements
  A->1 B->2 B->3 B->4 C->A
  1->D E->A 2->4 1->5 1->F
  E->6 4->6 5->7 6->7 3->8
}
")
```

It seems like Quarto and {DiagrammeR} don't play well together.
